text: the United States is beginning to get
results from the first intelligence
collection flights it has put over the
stricken reactors in Japan some of the
early results are encouraging others are
not the good news is that at least for
the radioactivity that's been detected
so far there is little sign that it is
extended a few miles beyond the
perimeter of the plant itself so the
evacuation area created by the Japanese
appears to be sufficient to be safe for
now the perimeter set by the United
States which is 50 miles around the
plant I looks right now to be a prudent
precaution but but if the wind shifted
it is possible that the plume of
radioactive material could make it out
into the area that the United States
think should be evacuated over the next
couple of days there's one measure to
look for what's happening to the
temperatures inside the reactors and
what's happening to the temperatures
inside those spent fuel rod ponds the
big concern is that the water from those
around those rods either leaked away or
boiled away and if they caught fire they
could begin to spew more radiation into
the atmosphere the number to look for is
whether the temperatures in any of those
locations are beginning to come down
